t: Lamentations 1
How*pn deserted lies the city, once*ld so full of people! How*ln like a widow is she, who*ld once was great among the nations! She*ln who was queen among the provinces has*ld now become a slave.
Bitterly*pn she weeps at night, tears*ld are on her cheeks. Among*ln all her lovers there*ld is no one to comfort her. All*ln her friends have betrayed her; they*ld have become her enemies.

After*pn affliction and harsh labor, Judah*ld has gone into exile. She*ln dwells among the nations; she*ld finds no resting place. All*ln who pursue her have overtaken her in*ld the midst of her distress.
The*pn roads to Zion mourn, for*ld no one comes to her appointed festivals. All*ln her gateways are desolate, her*ld priests groan, her*ln young women grieve, and*ld she is in bitter anguish.
Her*pn foes have become her masters; her*ld enemies are at ease. The*ln Lord*s has brought her grief because*ld of her many sins. Her*ln children have gone into exile, captive*ld before the foe.
All*pn the splendor has departed from*ld Daughter Zion. Her*ln princes are like deer that*ld find no pasture; in*ln weakness they have fled before*ld the pursuer.

In*pn the days of her affliction and wandering Jerusalem*ld remembers all the treasures that*ld were hers in days of old. When*ln her people fell into enemy hands, there*ld was no one to help her. Her*ln enemies looked at her and*ld laughed at her destruction.
Jerusalem*pn has sinned greatly and*ld so has become unclean. All*ln who honored her despise her, for*ld they have all seen her naked; she*ln herself groans and*ld turns away.

Her*pn filthiness clung to her skirts; she*ld did not consider her future. Her*ln fall was astounding; there*ld was none to comfort her. “Look,*ln Lord,*s on my affliction, for*ld the enemy has triumphed.”
The*pn enemy laid hands on*ld all her treasures; she*ln saw pagan nations enter*ld her sanctuary— those*ln you had forbidden to*ld enter your assembly.
All*pn her people groan as*ld they search for bread; they*ln barter their treasures for food to*ld keep themselves alive. “Look,*ln Lord,*s and consider, for*ld I am despised.”

“Is*pn it nothing to you, all you who pass by? Look*ld around and see. Is*ln any suffering like my suffering that*ld was inflicted on me, that*ln the Lord*s brought on me in*ld the day of his fierce anger?
“From*pn on high he sent fire, sent*ld it down into my bones. He*ln spread a net for my feet and*ld turned me back. He*ln made me desolate, faint*ld all the day long.

“My*pn sins have been bound into a yoke; by*ld his hands they were woven together. They*ln have been hung on my neck, and*ld the Lord has sapped my strength. He*ln has given me into the hands of*ld those I cannot withstand.
“The*pn Lord has rejected all*ld the warriors in my midst; he*ln has summoned an army against me to*ld crush my young men. In*ln his winepress the Lord has trampled Virgin*ld Daughter Judah.
“This*pn is why I weep and*ld my eyes overflow with tears. No*ln one is near to comfort me, no*ld one to restore my spirit. My*ln children are destitute because*ld the enemy has prevailed.”

Zion*pn stretches out her hands, but*ld there is no one to comfort her. The*ln Lord*s has decreed for Jacob that*ld his neighbors become his foes; Jerusalem*ln has become an*ld unclean thing among them.
“The*pn Lord*s is righteous, yet*ld I rebelled against his command. Listen,*ln all you peoples; look*ld on my suffering. My*ln young men and young women have*ld gone into exile.
“I*pn called to my allies but*ld they betrayed me. My*ln priests and my elders perished*ld in the city while*ln they searched for food to*ld keep themselves alive.
“See,*pn Lord,*s how distressed I am! I*ld am in torment within, and*ln in my heart I am disturbed, for*ld I have been most rebellious. Outside,*ln the sword bereaves; inside,*ld there is only death.

“People*pn have heard my groaning, but*ld there is no one to comfort me. All*ln my enemies have heard of my distress; they*ld rejoice at what you have done. May*ln you bring the day you have announced so*ld they may become like me.
“Let*pn all their wickedness come before you; deal*ld with them as*ln you have dealt with me because*ld of all my sins. My*ln groans are many and*ld my heart is faint.”
Lamentations 2

How*pn the Lord has covered Daughter Zion with*ld the cloud of his anger! He*ln has hurled down the splendor of Israel from*ld heaven to earth; he*ln has not remembered his footstool in*ld the day of his anger.

Without*pn pity the Lord has swallowed up all*ld the dwellings of Jacob; in*ln his wrath he has torn down the*ld strongholds of Daughter Judah. He*ln has brought her kingdom and its princes down*ld to the ground in dishonor.

In*pn fierce anger he has cut off every*ld horn of Israel. He*ln has withdrawn his right hand at*ld the approach of the enemy. He*ln has burned in Jacob like a flaming fire that*ld consumes everything around it.

Like*pn an enemy he has strung his bow; his*ld right hand is ready. Like*ln a foe he has slain all*ld who were pleasing to the eye; he*ln has poured out his wrath like fire on*ld the tent of Daughter Zion.

The*pn Lord is like an enemy; he*ld has swallowed up Israel. He*ln has swallowed up all her palaces and*ld destroyed her strongholds. He*ln has multiplied mourning and lamentation for*ld Daughter Judah.

He*pn has laid waste his dwelling like a garden; he*ld has destroyed his place of meeting. The*ln Lord*s has made Zion forget her*ld appointed festivals and her Sabbaths; in*ln his fierce anger he has spurned both*ld king and priest.

The*pn Lord has rejected his altar and*ld abandoned his sanctuary. He*ln has given the walls of her palaces into*ld the hands of the enemy; they*ln have raised a shout in the house of the Lord*s as*ld on the day of an appointed festival.

The*pn Lord*s determined to tear down the*ld wall around Daughter Zion. He*ln stretched out a measuring line and*ld did not withhold his hand from destroying. He*ln made ramparts and walls lament; together*ld they wasted away.

Her*pn gates have sunk into the ground; their*ld bars he has broken and destroyed. Her*ln king and her princes are exiled among the nations, the*ld law is no more, and*ln her prophets no longer find visions*ld from the Lord.*s

The*pn elders of Daughter Zion sit*ld on the ground in silence; they*ln have sprinkled dust on their heads and*ld put on sackcloth. The*ln young women of Jerusalem have*ld bowed their heads to the ground.

My*pn eyes fail from weeping, I*ld am in torment within; my*ln heart is poured out on the ground because*ld my people are destroyed, because*ln children and infants faint in*ld the streets of the city.
They*pn say to their mothers, “Where*ld is bread and wine?” as*ln they faint like the wounded in*ld the streets of the city, as*ln their lives ebb away in*ld their mothers’ arms.

What*pn can I say for you? With*ld what can I compare you, Daughter*ld Jerusalem? To*ln what can I liken you, that*ld I may comfort you, Virgin*ld Daughter Zion? Your*ln wound is as deep as the sea. Who*ld can heal you?
The*pn visions of your prophets were*ld false and worthless; they*ln did not expose your sin to*ld ward off your captivity. The*ln prophecies they gave you were*ld false and misleading.

All*pn who pass your way clap*ld their hands at you; they*ln scoff and shake their heads at*ld Daughter Jerusalem: “Is*ln this the city that was called the*ld perfection of beauty, the*ld joy of the whole earth?”

All*pn your enemies open their mouths wide*ld against you; they*ln scoff and gnash their teeth and*ld say, “We have swallowed her up. This*ln is the day we have waited for; we*ld have lived to see it.”

The*pn Lord*s has done what he planned; he*ld has fulfilled his word, which*ld he decreed long ago. He*ln has overthrown you without pity, he*ld has let the enemy gloat over you, he*ld has exalted the horn of your foes.
The*pn hearts of the people cry*ld out to the Lord. You*ln walls of Daughter Zion, let*ld your tears flow like a river day*ld and night; give*ln yourself no relief, your*ld eyes no rest.

Arise,*pn cry out in the night, as*ld the watches of the night begin; pour*ln out your heart like water in*ld the presence of the Lord. Lift*ln up your hands to him for*ld the lives of your children, who*ln faint from hunger at*ld every street corner.

“Look,*pn Lord,*s and consider: Whom*ld have you ever treated like this? Should*ln women eat their offspring, the*ld children they have cared for? Should*ln priest and prophet be killed in*ld the sanctuary of the Lord?

“Young*pn and old lie together in*ld the dust of the streets; my*ln young men and young women have*ld fallen by the sword. You*ln have slain them in the day of your anger; you*ld have slaughtered them without pity.

“As*pn you summon to a feast day, so*ld you summoned against me terrors on every side. In*ln the day of the Lord’s*s anger no*ld one escaped or survived; those*ln I cared for and reared my*ld enemy has destroyed.”
Lamentations 3
I*pn am the man who has seen affliction by*ld the rod of the Lord’s*s wrath.
He*ln has driven me away and made me walk in*ld darkness rather than light;
indeed,*ln he has turned his hand against me again*ld and again, all day long.
He*pn has made my skin and my flesh grow old and*ld has broken my bones.
He*ln has besieged me and surrounded me with*ld bitterness and hardship.
He*ln has made me dwell in darkness like*ld those long dead.
He*pn has walled me in so I cannot escape; he*ld has weighed me down with chains.
Even*ln when I call out or cry for help, he*ld shuts out my prayer.
He*ln has barred my way with blocks of stone; he*ld has made my paths crooked.
Like*pn a bear lying in wait, like*ld a lion in hiding,
he*ln dragged me from the path and mangled me and*ld left me without help.
He*ln drew his bow and*ld made me the target for his arrows.
He*pn pierced my heart with*ld arrows from his quiver.
I*ln became the laughingstock of all my people; they*ld mock me in song all day long.
He*ln has filled me with bitter herbs and*ld given me gall to drink.
He*pn has broken my teeth with gravel; he*ld has trampled me in the dust.
I*ln have been deprived of peace; I*ld have forgotten what prosperity is.
So*ln I say, “My splendor is gone and*ld all that I had hoped from the Lord.”*s
I*pn remember my affliction and my wandering, the*ld bitterness and the gall.
I*ln well remember them, and*ld my soul is downcast within me.
Yet*ln this I call to mind and*ld therefore I have hope:
Because*pn of the Lord’s*s great love we are not consumed, for*ld his compassions never fail.
They*ln are new every morning; great*ld is your faithfulness.
I*ln say to myself, “The Lord*s is my portion; therefore*ld I will wait for him.”
The*pn Lord*s is good to those whose hope is in him, to*ld the one who seeks him;
it*ln is good to wait quietly for*ld the salvation of the Lord.*s
It*ln is good for a man to bear the yoke while*ld he is young.
Let*pn him sit alone in silence, for*ld the Lord*s has laid it on him.
Let*ln him bury his face in the dust— there*ld may yet be hope.
Let*ln him offer his cheek to one who would strike him, and*ld let him be filled with disgrace.
For*pn no one is cast off by*ld the Lord forever.
Though*ln he brings grief, he will show compassion, so*ld great is his unfailing love.
For*ln he does not willingly bring affliction or*ld grief to anyone.
To*pn crush underfoot all*ld prisoners in the land,
to*ln deny people their rights before*ld the Most High,
to*ln deprive them of justice— would*ld not the Lord see such things?
Who*pn can speak and have it happen if*ld the Lord has not decreed it?
Is*ln it not from the mouth of the Most High that*ld both calamities and good things come?
Why*ln should the living complain when*ld punished for their sins?
Let*pn us examine our ways and test them, and*ld let us return to the Lord.*s
Let*ln us lift up our hearts and our hands to*ld God in heaven, and say:
“We*ln have sinned and rebelled and*ld you have not forgiven.
“You*pn have covered yourself with anger and pursued us; you*ld have slain without pity.
You*ln have covered yourself with a cloud so*ld that no prayer can get through.
You*ln have made us scum and refuse among*ld the nations.
“All*pn our enemies have opened their mouths wide*ld against us.
We*ln have suffered terror and pitfalls, ruin*ld and destruction.”
Streams*ln of tears flow from my eyes because*ld my people are destroyed.
My*pn eyes will flow unceasingly, without*ld relief,
until*ln the Lord*s looks down from*ld heaven and sees.
What*ln I see brings grief to my soul because*ld of all the women of my city.
Those*pn who were my enemies without cause hunted*ld me like a bird.
They*ln tried to end my life in a pit and*ld threw stones at me;
the*ln waters closed over my head, and*ld I thought I was about to perish.
I*pn called on your name, Lord,*s from*ld the depths of the pit.
You*ln heard my plea: “Do not close your ears to*ld my cry for relief.”
You*ln came near when I called you, and*ld you said, “Do not fear.”
You,*pn Lord, took up my case; you*ld redeemed my life.
Lord,*sln you have seen the wrong done to me. Uphold*ld my cause!
You*ln have seen the depth of their vengeance, all*ld their plots against me.
Lord,*spn you have heard their insults, all*ld their plots against me—
what*ln my enemies whisper and mutter against*ld me all day long.
Look*ln at them! Sitting or standing, they*ld mock me in their songs.
Pay*pn them back what they deserve, Lord,*s for*ld what their hands have done.
Put*ln a veil over their hearts, and*ld may your curse be on them!
Pursue*ln them in anger and destroy them from*ld under the heavens of the Lord.*s
Lamentations 4
How*pn the gold has lost its luster, the*ld fine gold become dull! The*ln sacred gems are scattered at*ld every street corner.
How*pn the precious children of Zion, once*ld worth their weight in gold, are*ln now considered as pots of clay, the*ld work of a potter’s hands!
Even*pn jackals offer their breasts to*ld nurse their young, but*ln my people have become heartless like*ld ostriches in the desert.
Because*pn of thirst the infant’s tongue sticks*ld to the roof of its mouth; the*ln children beg for bread, but*ld no one gives it to them.
Those*pn who once ate delicacies are*ld destitute in the streets. Those*ln brought up in royal purple now*ld lie on ash heaps.
The*pn punishment of my people is*ld greater than that of Sodom, which*ln was overthrown in a moment without*ld a hand turned to help her.
Their*pn princes were brighter than snow and*ld whiter than milk, their*ln bodies more ruddy than rubies, their*ld appearance like lapis lazuli.
But*pn now they are blacker than soot; they*ld are not recognized in the streets. Their*ln skin has shriveled on their bones; it*ld has become as dry as a stick.
Those*pn killed by the sword are better off than*ld those who die of famine; racked*ln with hunger, they waste away for*ld lack of food from the field.
With*pn their own hands compassionate women have*ld cooked their own children, who*ln became their food when*ld my people were destroyed.
The*pn Lord*s has given full vent to his wrath; he*ld has poured out his fierce anger. He*ln kindled a fire in Zion that*ld consumed her foundations.
The*pn kings of the earth did not believe, nor*ld did any of the peoples of the world, that*ln enemies and foes could enter the*ld gates of Jerusalem.
But*pn it happened because of the sins of her prophets and*ld the iniquities of her priests, who*ln shed within her the*ld blood of the righteous.
Now*pn they grope through the streets as*ld if they were blind. They*ln are so defiled with blood that*ld no one dares to touch their garments.
“Go*pn away! You are unclean!” people cry to them. “Away!*ld Away! Don’t touch us!” When*ln they flee and wander about, people*ld among the nations say, “They*ld can stay here no longer.”
The*pn Lord*s himself has scattered them; he*ld no longer watches over them. The*ln priests are shown no honor, the*ld elders no favor.
Moreover,*pn our eyes failed, looking*ld in vain for help; from*ln our towers we watched for*ld a nation that could not save us.
People*pn stalked us at every step, so*ld we could not walk in our streets. Our*ln end was near, our days were numbered, for*ld our end had come.
Our*pn pursuers were swifter than*ld eagles in the sky; they*ln chased us over the mountains and*ld lay in wait for us in the desert.
The*pn Lord’s*s anointed, our very life breath, was*ld caught in their traps. We*ln thought that under his shadow we*ld would live among the nations.
Rejoice*pn and be glad, Daughter Edom, you*ld who live in the land of Uz. But*ln to you also the cup will be passed; you*ld will be drunk and stripped naked.
Your*pn punishment will end, Daughter Zion; he*ld will not prolong your exile. But*ln he will punish your sin, Daughter Edom, and*ld expose your wickedness.
Lamentations 5
Remember,*pn Lord,*s what has happened to us; look,*ld and see our disgrace.
Our*ln inheritance has been turned over to strangers, our*ld homes to foreigners.
We*ln have become fatherless, our*ld mothers are widows.
We*ln must buy the water we drink; our*ld wood can be had only at a price.
Those*ln who pursue us are at our heels; we*ld are weary and find no rest.
We*ln submitted to Egypt and Assyria to*ld get enough bread.
Our*ln ancestors sinned and are no more, and*ld we bear their punishment.
Slaves*ln rule over us, and*ld there is no one to free us from their hands.
We*ln get our bread at the risk of our lives because*ld of the sword in the desert.
Our*ln skin is hot as an oven, feverish*ld from hunger.
Women*ln have been violated in Zion, and*ld virgins in the towns of Judah.
Princes*ln have been hung up by their hands; elders*ld are shown no respect.
Young*ln men toil at the millstones; boys*ld stagger under loads of wood.
The*ln elders are gone from the city gate; the*ld young men have stopped their music.
Joy*ln is gone from our hearts; our*ld dancing has turned to mourning.
The*ln crown has fallen from our head. Woe*ld to us, for we have sinned!
Because*ln of this our hearts are faint, because*ld of these things our eyes grow dim
for*ln Mount Zion, which lies desolate, with*ld jackals prowling over it.
You,*pn Lord,*s reign forever; your*ld throne endures from generation to generation.
Why*ln do you always forget us? Why*ld do you forsake us so long?
Restore*ln us to yourself, Lord,*s that we may return; renew*ld our days as of old
unless*ln you have utterly rejected us and*ld are angry with us beyond measure.
